'''Haringey Solidarity Group''' or '''HSG''' are a loose collective of [[anarchists]], [[socialists]], and [[community]] [[activists]] based in the [[London Borough of Haringey|Borough of Haringey]], [[London]].
==Aims==
HSG state that "We do not want to just become the new set of leaders!" <ref>http://www.haringey.org.uk/content/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=53&Itemid=67</ref> The group aims to support local community struggles and hopes that other community groups will support them, this is the source of the word [[wikt:solidarity|solidarity]] within their name. The group aims to practice, encourage and support self-organised struggles by ordinary people within Haringey, against bosses, local councils, or multi-national corporations. HSG also want to encourage other communities to organise themselves too, and Dave Morris a member of HSG has stated: "I want to see an independent residents' group in every street, a solidarity group in every workplace, and an anti-authoritarian/anti-capitalist organisation in every borough and town" <ref>Dave Morris. 20 years of organised anarchist, and related, activity in Haringey. ''KSL: Bulletin of the Kate Sharpley Library'' No. 29, January 2002. http://www.katesharpleylibrary.net/cvdp18</ref>
==History==
HSG were formed out of the remains of the Haringey [[Anti Poll Tax Union]], after the [[Community Charge|poll tax]] was defeated. "Originally set up to fight the poll tax, they decided to carry on after the tax was defeated." <ref>Schnews. 2001. 'Avin It In Haringey. In. Monopolise Resistance. http://www.schnews.org.uk/monopresist/monopoliseresistance/index.htm</ref> Initial hopes for several groups across the Borough proved to be unsustainable and after three years the groups were combined into one group. "In April 1991 we had the first meeting as Haringey Solidarity Group and by January 1992 we had formed three separate groups around the borough in Tottenham, Green Lanes, and Wood Green. Not being able to sustain three separate groups we all came back together as HSG in September 1994. " <ref>Anon. 2009. Haringey Solidarity Group - some activities past and present [1990-2005]. http://radicalhistorynetwork.blogspot.com/2009/09/haringey-solidarity-group-some.html Wednesday, September 2, 2009.</ref>
==Activities==
Members of HSG are active in their [[residents associations]] <ref>http://libcom.org/library/residents-take-over-community-organising</ref>, [[anti-fascism]], and [http://www.haringey.org.uk/ID.html Haringey Against ID], anti [[billboards]], anti [[debt]] campaigns, and various other antis. HSG continues to encourage [[tenants]] and [[workers]] [[self organisation]] throughout the borough, and have supported various workers struggles in the Borough of Haringey and beyond, including the 1995 JJ Foods Strike.<ref>http://libcom.org/library/1995-the-jj-foods-strike</ref> HSG members are also involved in organising free community festivals, the monthly [http://www.haringey.org.uk/hic/ Haringey Independent Cinema], and many other social events. Dave Morris and Helen Steel of the [[McLibel case]] are both involved with HSG.
